subject: RE: [junit]
msgSnippet: I don t think it breaks LSP.  The base class is TestCase (through AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest), the derived classes are your specific test cases.  They all
messageBody:
I don't think it breaks LSP. The base class is TestCase (through
AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest), the derived classes are your specific
test cases. They all act the same and their clients never know the
difference. Yes, if you create a new component you will have to add
that component to the abstract test case. So what? Nothing comes for
free... But, once it's added in, it is tested the same and thus your
ROI is extraordinarily positive! About coupling -- don't worry, your
test cases ought to be coupled to your tested objects! If they aren't,
they aren't really test cases. Or did I miss something?

FWIW: I don't worry too much about "good design", inheritance,
polymorphism, etc. in my test cases. I use it when I can see clearly
that it will save me time (and most often I refactor toward it)!
Otherwise they are generally pretty flat. Obviously, that doesn't apply
to the testing framework itself!!!!

=jason

On Wed, 2002-08-07 at 09:55, james.dobson@... wrote: This sounds
like a good approach but still it couples the test class and the
components it must test. In the future should I create a new component
I
will have to go back and alter the abstract test instead of
instantiating
the test with the newly created class. For some reason I think this
breaks
the Liskov Substitution Principle. And that can't be a good thing right
(sic)?

-----Original Message-----
From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jacaetevha@...]
Sent: 07 August 2002 15:41
To: JUnit Yahoo Group
Subject: Re: [junit]


A little cleaner approach would be to set them in lists and have the
tests iterate over the lists. Each test method then iterates over the
list of Components and performs its asserts/fails on each member of the
list. This list is most cleanly initialized in the abstract test's
setUp(). Of course that means that every time you execute a test, you
re-initialize the list of components (I would prefer that), but if you
don't want to do that use the TestSetup class.

There is really no need for embedding a class definition in the suite
method.

=jason

On Wed, 7 Aug 2002 17:17:43 +0400, "Kirill Maximov" <kir@...>
said:
> On 0, james.dobson@... wrote:
>
> I'm not quite sure that this will work, but it may:
>
> final TextComponent[] components = {
> new TextComponent(),
> new TextComponent("String")
> // more tested components
> };
>
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
>
> for (int i = 0; i < components.length; i++)
> {
> AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest test =
> new AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest()
> {
> public TextComponent getTestedComponent()
> {
> return components[i];
> }
> }
> suite.addTestSuite(test.getClass());
> }
> return suite;
>
> Just a thought,
> KIR
>
> > That was my first thought as well, and the solution I currently
have.
But
> > consider this......
> >
> > You can instantiate a JTextField 5 different ways and a JTextArea
6. So
> > using the system that (I think) we agree is the way to go we would
have
to
> > subclass AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest 5 times for JTextField and 6
times
> > for JTextArea. And in each subclass instantiate the Text Area/Field
> > differently. E.g.
> >
> > // sub class one
> > new JTextArea()
> >
> > //sub class two
> > new JTextArea("Second Type Of Constructor")
> >
> > // etc
> >
> > However you look at it you have to extend
AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest
N
> > times, where N equals the possible number of constructors (for the
different
> > objects) their are. I wanted to have N number of statements in one
class
> > (the Test Client) rather than N number of very 'thin' subclasses.
In
the
> > end I don't suppose it matters, the behaviour would be the same.
> >
> > I suppose what I was after was, in pseudo code, was something like
this:
> >
> > suite.addTestSuite(MyTestClass.class)
> > where component = new TextComponent()
> >
> > suite.addTestSuite(MyTestClass.class)
> > where component = new TextComponent("String")
> >
> > suite.addTestSuite(MyTestClass.class)
> > where component = new TextComponent(myDocument)
> >
> > etc etc etc
> >
> > Thanks for all the quick responses everyone.
> >
> > James
> >
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Mark Meyers [mailto:markm@...]
> > Sent: 07 August 2002 14:15
> > To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> > Subject: RE: [junit]
> >
> >
> > Sorry,
> >
> > Misunderstood, probably RTFM (Reda The F***ing Mail) syndrome on my
part.
> > What I think is the issue is that you should have an abstract test
case
> > AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest that contains all testXxx() methods
and an
> > instance variable of type JTextfield. Then make concrete subclasses
> > (ChildATest, ChildBTest,...), in the setUp you instantiate the
correct
one:
> >
> > public class ChildBTest extends AbstractEnhancedTextfieldTest {
> > public void setUp(){
> > setMyTextfield(new ChildA());
> > }
> > }
> >
> > and then in the TestSuite:
> >
> > public static Test suite()
> > {
> > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> >
> > suite.addTest(new TestSuite(ChildATest.class));
> > suite.addTest(new TestSuite(ChildBTest.class));
> > return suite;
> > }
> >
> > Even nicer would be to use a factory method in the concrete
children.
> > > -----Original Message-----
> > > From: james.dobson@... [mailto:james.dobson@...]
> > > Sent: woensdag 7 augustus 2002 13:36
> > > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > > Subject: RE: [junit]
> > >
> > >
> > > Hi Mark,
> > >
> > > Maybe I missed the point: I thought that the constructor of
> > > TestSuite took
> > > a class, but that class should contain some tests.
> > > In my situation I have a test MyTest that runs a number of
> > > tests against a
> > > JTextComponent. ChildA and ChildB are types of
> > > JTextComponent and do not
> > > contain any tests. I want to pass ChildA and ChildB to MyTest so
that
> > > MyTest can test these different subclasses of JTextComponent.
> > >
> > > -----Original Message-----
> > > From: Mark Meyers [mailto:markm@...]
> > > Sent: 07 August 2002 12:41
> > > To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
> > > Subject: RE: [junit]
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > public static Test suite()
> > > {
> > > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> > >
> > > suite.addTest(new TestSuite(ChildA.class));
> > > suite.addTest(new TestSuite(ChildB.class));
> > > return suite;
> > > }
> > >
> > > > -----Original Message-----
> > > > From: james.dobson@... [mailto:james.dobson@...]
> > > > Sent: woensdag 7 augustus 2002 12:27
> > > > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > > > Subject: [junit]
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > Hi Everyone,
> > > >
> > > > Is it possible to automatically add all the tests of a test
> > > > class to a suite
> > > > without using 'suite.addTestSuite(MyTest.class)'?
> > > >
> > > > I have a test class that can test a number of classes from the
same
> > > > hierarchy. Let's say for arguments sake that I have
> > > created two child
> > > > classes (ChildA and ChildB) of type JTextComponent and both
> > > > of them override
> > > > a number of methods such as setText. I have a number of
> > > > tests that test the
> > > > newly overridden methods. I have created a constructor for
> > > > the class that
> > > > looks something like this:
> > > >
> > > > public MyTest(String name, JTextComponent component)
> > > > {
> > > > super(name);
> > > > this.component = component;
> > > > }
> > > >
> > > > My problem is this: I want to run this test twice, once for
> > > > childA and once
> > > > for childB. But I don't want to type in the tests individually
e.g.
> > > >
> > > > public class MyTestClient
> > > > {
> > > > public static Test suite()
> > > > {
> > > > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> > > >
> > > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test1", new
> > > > ChildA()));
> > > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test2", new
> > > > ChildA()));
> > > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test3", new
> > > > ChildA()));
> > > > ........
> > > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("testN", new
> > > > ChildA()));
> > > >
> > > > // Then the same for childB

> > > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test1", new
> > > > ChildB()));
> > > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test2", new
> > > > ChildB()));
> > > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test3", new
> > > > ChildB()));
> > > > ........
> > > > suite.addTest(new MyTest("testN", new
> > > > ChildB()));
> > > > return suite;
> > > > }
> > > > public static void main(String[] args)
> > > > {
> > > >
junit.swingui.TestRunner.run(MyTestClient.class);
> > > > }
> > > > }
> > > >
> > > > How I would like to write the suite method is something like
this:
> > > >
> > > > public static Test suite()
> > > > {
> > > > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> > > >
> > > > suite.addTest(MyTest.class /** Parameter here
> > > > to indicate I
> > > > want to test ChildA */)
> > > > suite.addTest(MyTest.class /** Parameter here
> > > > to indicate I
> > > > want to test ChildB */)
> > > > }
> > > >
> > > > Hope this is a sensible question!
> > > >
> > > > James
> > > >
